article.description: Texas Tech has won two straight games for the first time since January, but Bob Knight is hardly excited.
article.headline: Knight gets 830th win
article.linkText: Texas Tech tops Cyclones to end regular season
article.story: LUBBOCK, Texas (AP) -- Texas Tech has won two straight games for the first time since January, but Bob Knight is hardly excited. The Red Raiders head into next week's Big 12 tournament after beating Iowa State 72-58 Saturday, three days after an 87-76 victory over Missouri. "Today's game has nothing to do with the next," Knight said. "Winning today is ... a bigger step than having beaten Missouri was because we have not always been mature enough to come back and do something pretty good and then follow that up with something pretty good or something better." The mini-streak ends a 3-7 stretch that knocked the Red Raiders out of the Top 25. Tech had won 12 straight before then. On Saturday, Ronald Ross scored 23 points to give Knight his 830th career win, tying Jimmy Phelan, who retired from Mount St. Mary's last year after 49 seasons. Knight, in his 38th season, trails only Dean Smith of North Carolina (879) and Adolph Rupp of Kentucky (876) among Division I male coaches. The Red Raiders finished the regular season with only one loss at home, a 62-61 overtime loss to then-No. 16 Texas in late February. Trailing by 13 at halftime, the Cyclones (16-11, 7-9 Big 12) pulled to withing 36-44 early in the second half. But Tech (21-9, 9-7) used a 9-3 run to go up 53-39 on a steal and layup by Jarrius Jackson with 11:28 remaining. Iowa State, which finished with 23 turnovers, failed to mount a serious threat after that. "That is too many (turnovers) against a team like Texas Tech," said Iowa State coach Wayne Morgan. "Our offensive execution was poor all day, and we needed to do a better job rebounding." The Red Raiders got their largest lead at 72-54 on a slam dunk by Ross with 1:21 left. Tech's win was the result of hot shooting. The team hit on 28 of 55 from the field or 51 percent. Jackson scored 17 points, while Devonne Giles added 12 for Tech Curtis Stinson scored 17 points, and Jackson Vroman and Jared Homan got 13 each to lead the Cyclones. Saturday was senior day, and after the game Knight tried to pay tribute to Andre Emmett, Mikey Marshall and Robert Tomaszek. But Ross was being interviewed on television. "Ronald, Ronald," Knight yelled across the floor at Ross, who was at midcourt being interviewed. "That's enough. Say goodbye to ABC." Then Knight went on. "We wound this thing up pretty well," Knight told the crowd. "They probably wouldn't agree with this, but I've enjoyed these kids very much." At the post-game news conference, Knight lauded Emmett, who led the conference in scoring (21.2 points) coming into the game. "I think what he's done as a player speaks for itself," Knight said. "Here's a kid that graduates easily right on time. Now on the floor there've been a few problems but off the floor, not the first problem whatsoever, in any way, shape or form, and that's something I have a great respect for." Tech led 42-29 at halftime. The Red Raiders used runs of 20-6 and 11-2 to build its largest first half-lead at 40-24 with about a minute remaining. In the latter run, Ross got seven on two 3-pointers and a free throw, while Giles got the other five.
